Award.AbstractNarration:
Award Title:
The Role of Frontal Cortex in Primate Metacognition

Award Abstract:
Rarely do we stop thinking. The mental experience of humans is one of continuity, with thoughts leading to other thoughts. When we reflect on our past decisions and ponder how we may act in the future, we are manipulating our own thought processes, a process termed metacognition. Most research on thought processes at both the psychological and neural levels has focused on single events such as how we remember a picture or decide our next move in a game of chess. Little is understood about serial cognitive events, such as the chain of decisions required to plan several moves ahead in chess. Understanding how individual thought processes influence each other -- venturing beyond cognition to metacognition -- is a challenging but important next step for brain research. Dr. Marc Sommer at Duke University studies metacognition using novel approaches that combine psychological experiments with direct recordings of neurons in the brain. With his Duke colleague, computational neuroscientist Dr. Jeff Beck, he examines not only how decisions are made, but also how they are remembered and controlled. Psychological testing of humans and non-human primates reveal how well they adjust their decision-making when circumstances change, and computer-aided modeling of the data allows for precise comparisons of metacognitive abilities between subjects and species. Neural recordings from the frontal cortex of non-human primates while they control their own decisions sheds light on how the brain is able to link thoughts across time. Specific implications of this work include a better understanding of human cognition and behavior in fast-paced and unpredictable situations that require constant evaluation and planning of decisions. The project will offer hands-on laboratory training opportunities for undergraduates and high school students and will be highlighted in STEM outreach to K12 schools, community lectures, and lay articles on cognitive neuroscience. The research aligns with the public's emerging interest in metacognition as an important factor in education, mental health, and the management of oneself and others.

The experimental approach is to use an integrated set of psychophysical and neurophysiological studies in which all data are analyzed and interpreted with computational modeling. The rationale for the project is that humans are adept at metacognitive operations, for example thinking about how to make a later decision, but little is known about the underlying neural mechanisms. Dr. Sommer previously recorded from neurons in the monkey frontal lobe and discovered signals in one area, the supplementary eye field (SEF), that maintained a trace of past decisions. The overall hypothesis of this proposal is that the SEF contributes, as well, to the metacognitive control of future decisions. The first objective is to quantify metacognitive behavior in monkeys as compared with humans. Both species will be tested on a novel rule selection task. Within a trial, subjects select a rule for making a visual decision (metacognitive control), but across trials, subjects bias their rule selection based on past outcomes (metacognitive monitoring). The second objective is to determine whether SEF activity is related to metacognitive control and monitoring. The approach will be to record from neurons in monkey SEF during the rule selection task. The third objective is to test whether the SEF is necessary for metacognitive control and monitoring. The approach will be to reversibly inactivate the monkey SEF during the rule selection task. Dr. Beck will assist with modeling and analysis of the data to ensure all results are statistically sound and clearly interpretable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans are adept at coordinating their decisions, memories, and predictions. The ability to link cognitive operations across time -- to monitor past cognitive functions and control future ones -- is termed metacognition. The overall intellectual merit of our project was to help transform the psychological concept of metacognition into the domain of cognitive neuroscience using tightly integrated behavioral and neurophysiological experiments. Our approach was to quantify the metacognitive abilities of non-human primates, as benchmarked to human subjects, and then study how the brain operates to produce those abilities. We trained rhesus monkeys to perform a task in which they selected between visual stimuli based on a rule such as “pick the smaller one”. On any trial of the task, the monkey was either given the rule or was allowed to select the rule. The ability to link selection of the rule to later use of the rule is termed metacognitive control. We found, first, that the monkeys learned to perform the task rationally rather than randomly. On a daily basis, they preferred to select the rules that they were better at. Moreover, they remembered their self-selected rules and used them properly for the visual discrimination. This behavioral result was critical in confirming that the animals could use metacognitive operations, thus providing the rationale to study those operations at the level of individual neurons in the brain.

We then recorded from neurons in the monkeys’ frontal cortex as they performed the task. We predicted that we would find neural activity that linked the rule to the later decision, and we found it. Surprisingly, however, the activity did not continue non-stop from rule selection to rule use. Instead, the activity appeared only a few moments before the rule had to be used, a “just in time” signal. The main conclusion was that the neurons we studied engaged in metacognitive control for the purpose of initiating behavior. Other neurons must be involved in the more purely cognitive operation of keeping the rule “in mind” regardless of how, or whether, it is used. In parallel, we tested human subjects on metacognitive control tasks and used computational modeling to analyze both the human and monkey behavior. We found a mixture of cognitive strategies at play, with humans showing an especially flexible and sophisticated set of metacognitive operations. Results from the project were published in The Journal of Neuroscience and The Journal of Experimental Psychology: Animal Learning and Cognition.

The broader impacts of the project included the training of a PhD student who won our departmental award for outstanding dissertation and, in addition to all his data papers, a book chapter and encyclopedia entry co-written by the student to communicate the work broadly to the field. An undergraduate student and two high school students also participated in the project. PI Sommer built on this high school outreach to help found the Duke Research in Engineering Program (DukeREP), which he has led as faculty advisor for the past three years. DukeREP recruits and supports high school juniors and seniors, many of them from groups underrepresented in science, to spend a summer performing research in Duke laboratories. The DukeREP students also participate in college advising workshops held by the Duke College Advising Corps, writing workshops, professional skills development workshops held by the Duke Career Center, and a series of talks by professors about the NEA Grand Challenges for Engineering. The college advising workshops familiarize students with the college application process, touching on topics such as the common application, the SATs, and financial aid. The writing workshops guide students through writing their common application essay. The professional skills development workshops touch on communication skills, interview skills, and resume writing. Each summer, the program culminates in a poster session during which students present their work to their friends, family, and the Duke community. So far, DukeREP has trained 17 high school students, 13 of whom were from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM. We are now soliciting applications for our third year of DukeREP and aim to double those numbers this coming summer.
